detaileddescription.para: Enable parsing of recolor command
Ignore max-width to avoid automatic word wrapping
Align the text to the middle
Align the text to the right
Max-width is already equal to the longest line. (Used to skip some calculation)
Options for text rendering.
Waiting for command
Processing the parameter
Processing the command
State machine for text renderer.

Give the size of an encoded character
str
pointer to a character in a string
length of the encoded character (1,2,3 ...). O in invalid

Convert an Unicode letter to encoded
letter_uni
an Unicode letter
Encoded character in Little Endian to be compatible with C chars (e.g. 'Á', 'Ü')

Convert a wide character, e.g. 'Á' little endian to be compatible with the encoded format.
c
a wide character
c in the encoded format

Decode the next encoded character from a string.
txt
pointer to '\0' terminated string
i
start index in 'txt' where to start. After the call it will point to the next encoded char in 'txt'. NULL to use txt[0] as index
the decoded Unicode character or 0 on invalid data code

Get the previous encoded character form a string.
txt
pointer to '\0' terminated string
i_start
index in 'txt' where to start. After the call it will point to the previous encoded char in 'txt'.
the decoded Unicode character or 0 on invalid data

Convert a letter index (in an the encoded text) to byte index. E.g. in UTF-8 "AÁRT" index of 'R' is 2 but start at byte 3 because 'Á' is 2 bytes long
txt
a '\0' terminated UTF-8 string
enc_id
letter index
byte index of the 'enc_id'th letter

Convert a byte index (in an encoded text) to character index. E.g. in UTF-8 "AÁRT" index of 'R' is 2 but start at byte 3 because 'Á' is 2 bytes long
txt
a '\0' terminated UTF-8 string
byte_id
byte index
character index of the letter at 'byte_id'th position

Get the number of characters (and NOT bytes) in a string. E.g. in UTF-8 "ÁBC" is 3 characters (but 4 bytes)
txt
a '\0' terminated char string
number of characters

memberdef.argsstring: (lv_point_t *size_res, const char *text, const lv_font_t *font, lv_coord_t letter_space, lv_coord_t line_space, lv_coord_t max_width, lv_txt_flag_t flag)
memberdef.name: _lv_txt_get_size

detaileddescription.para:
Get size of a text
size_res
pointer to a 'point_t' variable to store the result
text
pointer to a text
font
pointer to font of the text
letter_space
letter space of the text
line_space
line space of the text
flags
settings for the text from 'txt_flag_t' enum
max_width
max with of the text (break the lines to fit this size) Set CORD_MAX to avoid line breaks

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *txt, const lv_font_t *font, lv_coord_t letter_space, lv_coord_t max_width, lv_txt_flag_t flag)
memberdef.name: _lv_txt_get_next_line

detaileddescription.para:
Get the next line of text. Check line length and break chars too.
txt
a '\0' terminated string
font
pointer to a font
letter_space
letter space
max_width
max with of the text (break the lines to fit this size) Set CORD_MAX to avoid line breaks
flags
settings for the text from 'txt_flag_type' enum
the index of the first char of the new line (in byte index not letter index. With UTF-8 they are different)

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *txt, uint32_t length, const lv_font_t *font, lv_coord_t letter_space, lv_txt_flag_t flag)
memberdef.name: _lv_txt_get_width

detaileddescription.para:
Give the length of a text with a given font
txt
a '\0' terminate string
length
length of 'txt' in byte count and not characters (Á is 1 character but 2 bytes in UTF-8)
font
pointer to a font
letter_space
letter space
flags
settings for the text from 'txt_flag_t' enum
length of a char_num long text

Check next character in a string and decide if the character is part of the command or not
state
pointer to a txt_cmd_state_t variable which stores the current state of command processing
c
the current character
true: the character is part of a command and should not be written, false: the character should be written

Insert a string into an other
txt_buf
the original text (must be big enough for the result text)
pos
position to insert (0: before the original text, 1: after the first char etc.)
ins_txt
text to insert

Delete a part of a string
txt
string to modify
pos
position where to start the deleting (0: before the first char, 1: after the first char etc.)
len
number of characters to delete

return a new formatted text. Memory will be allocated to store the text.
fmt
printf-like format
pointer to the allocated text string.
